chapter.title: Configuring Clients to Use ⪪
chapter.para: Any machine running &sle; 10 SP4 or 11 SP1 (or later) can be configured to register against ⪪ and download software updates from there, instead of communicating directly with the Customer Center and the ν servers.

If your network includes an ⪪ server to provide a local update source, you need to equip the client with the server's URL. As client and server communicate via the HTTPS protocol during registration, you also need to make sure the client trusts the server's certificate. In case you set up your ⪪ server to use the default server certificate, the CA certificate will be available on the ⪪ server at http://FQDN/smt.crt . In this case you do not have to manually set the certificate: The registration process will automatically download the CA certificate from there, unless configured otherwise. You must enter a path to the server's CA certificate if the certificate was issued by an external certificate authority.

note.title: Registering Against *.novell.com Subdomain
note.para: If you try to register against any *.novell.com subdomain, the certificate will not be downloaded during registration for security reasons, and certificate handling will not be done. In such a case, use a different domain name or a plain IP address.

chapter.para: There are several ways to provide the registration information and to configure the client machine to use ⪪:

listitem.para: Provide the needed information via kernel parameters at boot time ().
Configure the clients using an &ay; profile ().
Use the clientSetup4SMT.sh script (). This script can be run on a client to make it register against a specified ⪪ server.
In &sle; 11 you can now set the ⪪ server URL with the &yast; registration module during installation ().

chapter.para: These methods are described in the following sections.

sect1.title: Using Kernel Parameters to Access an ⪪ Server
sect1.para: Any client can be configured to use ⪪ by providing the following kernel parameters during machine boot: regurl and regcert. The first parameter is mandatory, the latter is optional.

warning.title: Beware of Typing Errors
warning.para: Make sure the values you enter are correct. If regurl has not been specified correctly, the registration of the update source will fail.

If an invalid value for regcert has been entered, you will be prompted for a local path to the certificate. In case regcert is not specified at all, it will default to http://FQDN/smt.crt with FQDN being the name of the ⪪ server.

listitem.para: For SLE 11 and older clients, the URL needs to be in the following format: https://FQDN/center/regsvc/ with FQDN being the fully qualified hostname of the ⪪ server. It must be identical to the FQDN of the server certificate used on the ⪪ server. Example:

warning.title: Change of ⪪ Server Certificate
warning.para: If the ⪪ server gets a new certificate from a new and untrusted CA, the clients need to retrieve the new CA certificate file. This is done automatically with the registration process but only if a URL was used at installation time to retrieve the certificate, or if the regcert parameter was omitted and thus, the default URL is used. If the certificate was loaded using any other method, such as floppy or local path, the CA certificate will not be updated.

sect1.title: Configuring Clients with &ay; Profile
sect1.para: To configure ⪪ specific data using &ay;, follow these steps:

step.para: As &rootuser;, start &yast; and select Miscellaneous Autoinstallation to start the graphical &ay; front-end.
From a command line, you can start the graphical &ay; front-end with the yast2 autoyast command.
Open an existing profile using File Open , create a profile based on the current system's configuration using Tools Create Reference Profile , or just work with an empty profile.
In SLE 11, select Software Novell Customer Center Configuration . An overview of the current configuration is shown.
Click Configure.

Set the URL of the ⪪ Server and, optionally, the location of the ⪪ Certificate. The possible values are the same as for the kernel parameters regurl and regcert (see ). The only exception is that the ask value for regcert does not work in &ay;, because it requires user interaction. If using it, the registration process will be skipped.
Perform all other configuration needed for the systems to be deployed.
Select File Save As and enter a filename for the profile, such as autoinst.xml.

sect1.title: Configuring Clients with the clientSetup4SMT.sh Script in SLE 11
sect1.para: In SLE 11, the /usr/share/doc/packages/smt/clientSetup4SMT.sh script is provided with ⪪. This script allows you to configure a client machine to use an ⪪ server. It can also be used to reconfigure an existing client to use a different ⪪ server.

note.title: Installation of wget
note.para: The script clientSetup4SMT.sh itself uses wget, so wget must be installed on the client.

sect1.para: To configure a client machine to use ⪪ with the clientSetup4SMT.sh script, follow these steps:

step.para: Copy the clientSetup4SMT.sh script from your ⪪ server to the client machine. The script is available at <SMT_HOSTNAME>/repo/tools/clientSetup4SMT.sh and /srv/www/htdocs/repo/tools/clientSetup4SMT.sh. You can download it with a browser, using wget, or by another means, such as with scp.
As &rootuser;, execute the script on the client machine. The script can be executed in two ways. In the first case, the script name is followed by the registration URL; for example:
In this case, without any namespace specified, the client will be configured to use the default production repositories. If --namespace groupname is specified, the client will use that staging group.
The script downloads the server's CA certificate. Accept it by pressing y.
The script performs all necessary modifications on the client. However, the registration itself is not performed by the script.
The script downloads and asks to accept additional GPG keys to sign repositories with.
Perform a registration by executing suse_register or running yast2 inst_suse_register module on the client.

sect2.title: Problems Downloading GPG Keys from the Server
sect2.para: The apache2-example-pages package includes a robots.txt file. The file is installed into the Apache2 document root directory, and controls how clients can access files from the web server. If this package is installed on the server, clientSetup4SMT.sh fails to download the keys stored under /repo/keys.
You can solve this problem by either editing robots.txt, or uninstalling the apache2-example-pages package.

sect2.title: Configuring Clients with &yast; in SLE 11
sect2.para: To configure a client to perform the registration against an ⪪ server use the &yast; registration module (yast2 inst_suse_register).
Click AdvancedLocal Registration Server and enter the name of the ⪪ server plus the path to the registration internals (/center/regsvc/), e.g.:
After confirmation the certificate is loaded and the user is asked to accept it. Then continue.

warning.title: Staging Groups Registration
warning.para: If a staging group is used, make sure that settings in /etc/suseRegister.conf are done accordingly. If not already done, modify the register= paramater and append &namespace=namespace. For more information about staging groups, see .

sect2.title: Configuring Clients with &yast; in SLE 12
sect2.para: To configure a client to perform the registration against an ⪪ server use the &yast; SUSE Customer Center Configuration module (yast2 scc).
On the client, the credentials are not necessary and you may leave the relevant fields empty. Click Local Registration Server and enter its url. Then click Next until the exit from the module.

sect1.para: To retrieve the accessible repositories for a client, download repo/repoindex.xml from the ⪪ server with the client's credentials. The credentials are stored in /etc/zypp/credentials.d/NCCCredentials on the client machine. Using wget, the command for testing could be as follows:
repoindex.xml returns the complete repository list as they come from the vendor. If a repository is marked for staging, repoindex.xml lists the repository in the full namespace (repos/full/$RCE).
To get a list of all repositories available on the ⪪ server, use the credentials specified in the [LOCAL] section of /etc/smt.conf on the server as mirrorUser and mirrorPassword.

sect1.title: How to Update Red Hat Enterprise Linux with SMT 11
